newsitem.title: HONG KONG: Hong Kong stocks close moderately lower.
newsitem.headline: Hong Kong stocks close moderately lower.

text.p: Hong Kong stocks closed moderately lower on Thursday in cautious trading, pulled down by profit-taking in the market leaders particularly property stocks, brokers said.

"It is hard for the market to make headway with the U.S. long bond yield at current levels," said Chris Geiger, associate director of Vickers Ballas. "But the lower volume is a good sign and confirms we are just in a trading range."
The Hang Seng Index closed 82.46 points lower at 13,610.33, slightly above the day's low of 13,591.35. Turnover was HK$8.28 billion, well off Wednesday's HK$11.16 billion.
The U.S. 30-year Treasury closed Wednesday trading in New York off 19/32 at 95-24/32 to yield 6.83 compared with 6.79 on Tuesday.
Chartists said the 6.90 percent level is the danger zone, indicating a possibility of higher U.S. and Hong Kong interest rates.
"We saw quite a bit of switching, out of properties, and into laggards like Hongkong Electric," said one local broker.
Hongkong Electric closed the day unchanged at HK$27.00.
Brokers said there was some concern that direct Sino-Taiwan shipping links would have a negative impact on the territory's economy, but the magnitude would not be great.
Properties led the market down, followed by the utilities. Only the finance sector managed a positive performance.
New World Development lost HK$1.15 to HK$49.60 and Henderson Land slipped HK$1.00 to HK$72.25.
In the utility sector, Hongkong Telecom lost HK$0.20 to HK$13.25 and HK & China Gas slipped HK$0.15 to HK$14.60.
Infrstructure plays were active. New World Infrastructure gained HK$0.25 to HK$22.45, while Cheung Kong Infrastructure was unchanged at HK$22.40.
"Infrastructure plays with high quality earnings and good growth potential may come to replace utilities in Hong Kong/China portfolios," said Vickers' Geiger.
In the finance sector, HSBC made a late advance of HK$1.50 to end the day at HK$180.00, while Hang Seng Bank led the loss leaders with a fall of HK$1.75 to HK$91.50.

CITIC Pacific dropped HK$1.00 to HK$38.20 on heavy volume of HK$552.72 million. Brokers said the share was likely to continue to be weak, due to the large discount to market of the 15.47 percent stake offered to management at HK$33.00 per share.
H share sector market leaders suffered heavy profit taking.
Guangdong Kelon plunged HK$0.20 to HK$5.75 and Tsingtao Brewery slid HK$0.15 to HK$3.10.
Red chip China Pharmaceutical put on HK$0.04 to HK$1.15.
